texts.text: {{< alert >}} All comments and thoughts in this post are my own and certainly do not reflect the positions of any of my employers, past and present. The goal of this post is to help with healing after a layoff event and organizing your thoughts around your decisions afterwards. {{< /alert >}}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Whatever you want to call them -- layoffs, reductions in force, or downsizing -- they're terrible.
texts.text: Whatever you want to call them -- layoffs, reductions in force, or downsizing -- they're terrible.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For those who leave, uncertainty can become overwhelming. Loss of work means a loss of salary on the simplest level, but it can also mean a loss of purpose. It can mean a loss of critical medical insurance benefits.
texts.text: For those who leave, uncertainty can become overwhelming. Loss of work means a loss of salary on the simplest level, but it can also mean a loss of purpose. It can mean a loss of critical medical insurance benefits.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For those who stay, layoffs shake the foundations of trust with the employer. I have a whole blog post on  red flags  that goes into detail on this topic, so I won't repeat it all here.
texts.text: For those who stay, layoffs shake the foundations of trust with the employer. I have a whole blog post on  red flags  that goes into detail on this topic, so I won't repeat it all here.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My argument in this post is that for those who stay and recommit to the mission of the business,  you have much more control over customer outcomes than you ever did before.
texts.text: My argument in this post is that for those who stay and recommit to the mission of the business,  you have much more control over customer outcomes than you ever did before.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: How to think about layoffs
texts.text: How to think about layoffs

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I went through several rounds of layoffs at my last employer and my current employer just did a round. Engineers around me often say things like:
texts.text: I went through several rounds of layoffs at my last employer and my current employer just did a round. Engineers around me often say things like:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: "How could they let him go? He was so helpful!"
texts.text: "How could they let him go? He was so helpful!"

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: "She is critical to this project and it's our top priority. How could she leave now?"
texts.text: "She is critical to this project and it's our top priority. How could she leave now?"

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: "He was there for 24 years and he helped everyone, even our CEO. Why would they make him go?"
texts.text: "He was there for 24 years and he helped everyone, even our CEO. Why would they make him go?"

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: "Our quarterly results looked great. Why does anyone need to be laid off?"
texts.text: "Our quarterly results looked great. Why does anyone need to be laid off?"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The first step is to avoid  reading deeply into the decision  and avoid  making it personal .
texts.text: The first step is to avoid  reading deeply into the decision  and avoid  making it personal .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In my experience, some of the decisions are made based on data that you can't see at a publicly traded company. Sometimes a company sheds employees simply because everyone in their market sector is doing it and they're looking for a temporary bump in the stock price. And then there are those situations where a company chooses to end a product line or project.
texts.text: In my experience, some of the decisions are made based on data that you can't see at a publicly traded company. Sometimes a company sheds employees simply because everyone in their market sector is doing it and they're looking for a temporary bump in the stock price. And then there are those situations where a company chooses to end a product line or project.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These decisions are often made at a high level within the company and done in such a way to avoid any type of employment-related lawsuits. That brings me to my next topic.
texts.text: These decisions are often made at a high level within the company and done in such a way to avoid any type of employment-related lawsuits. That brings me to my next topic.

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Why do they let top performers go?
texts.text: Why do they let top performers go?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This frustrated me many times over the years. As an example, there was a talented network engineer on a team who was a rising star in the company. He could work through complex network topologies to provide a balance of performance and security based on the customer's demands.
texts.text: This frustrated me many times over the years. As an example, there was a talented network engineer on a team who was a rising star in the company. He could work through complex network topologies to provide a balance of performance and security based on the customer's demands.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Even better, he could explain it all to customers. Better still, he could explain it to the customer's technical and non-technical staff.
texts.text: Even better, he could explain it all to customers. Better still, he could explain it to the customer's technical and non-technical staff.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The customer was getting closer to making the deal and this engineer was central to the deal being made. The deal was  large . Everyone was preparing with implementation calls, documents, and everything else needed for the final meeting.
texts.text: The customer was getting closer to making the deal and this engineer was central to the deal being made. The deal was  large . Everyone was preparing with implementation calls, documents, and everything else needed for the final meeting.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The final meeting came, but the network engineer wasn't on the call.
texts.text: The final meeting came, but the network engineer wasn't on the call.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Salespeople, solutions architects, and other engineers were frantic. Did he go home sick? Did we send him the wrong time on the calendar invitation?
texts.text: Salespeople, solutions architects, and other engineers were frantic. Did he go home sick? Did we send him the wrong time on the calendar invitation?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: No, as it turns out, he was laid off at lunch and the call was scheduled for 2PM.
texts.text: No, as it turns out, he was laid off at lunch and the call was scheduled for 2PM.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A choice was made to reduce engineering staff by some percentage, so the business essentially did this:
texts.text: A choice was made to reduce engineering staff by some percentage, so the business essentially did this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE job_family = "engineering"
ORDER BY RAND()
LIMIT 100
texts.text:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE job_family = "engineering"
ORDER BY RAND()
LIMIT 100

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: And they went through the list methodically until their percentage was met.
texts.text: And they went through the list methodically until their percentage was met.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is why taking layoffs personally will only cause you pain. Avoid looking for a deeper meaning and explanation where one does not exist.
texts.text: This is why taking layoffs personally will only cause you pain. Avoid looking for a deeper meaning and explanation where one does not exist.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As Yoda once said:
texts.text: As Yoda once said:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fear is the path to the dark side. Fear leads to anger. Anger leads to hate. Hate leads to suffering.
texts.text: Fear is the path to the dark side. Fear leads to anger. Anger leads to hate. Hate leads to suffering.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: How about the people who aren't top performers?
texts.text: How about the people who aren't top performers?

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Why don't companies just lay off low performers?
texts.text: Why don't companies just lay off low performers?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (Again, try to to avoid looking for deeper meaning here, but I'll go through this question anyway.)
texts.text: (Again, try to to avoid looking for deeper meaning here, but I'll go through this question anyway.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've heard this many times and I've asked it myself before:
texts.text: I've heard this many times and I've asked it myself before:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Why don't companies just lay off the low performers? After all, some of these people might be toxic to teams and it's clear they're not committed to the company mission.
texts.text: Why don't companies just lay off the low performers? After all, some of these people might be toxic to teams and it's clear they're not committed to the company mission.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's a good argument! If a company wants to save money by spending less on salaries and benefits, why not target the people who aren't doing the work first? You'd reduce expenses while improving the quality of the workforce!
texts.text: It's a good argument! If a company wants to save money by spending less on salaries and benefits, why not target the people who aren't doing the work first? You'd reduce expenses while improving the quality of the workforce!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Long story short:  It's not that simple.
texts.text: Long story short:  It's not that simple.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A wise manager once told me that:
texts.text: A wise manager once told me that:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're the last person to find out that your performance is inadequate, that's not your fault. It's your manager's fault.
texts.text: If you're the last person to find out that your performance is inadequate, that's not your fault. It's your manager's fault.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Managers make mistakes. Whether they're mistakes made on purpose or not, it often opens the company up to litigation.
texts.text: Managers make mistakes. Whether they're mistakes made on purpose or not, it often opens the company up to litigation.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For example, a manager might label an employee as a low performer due to factors outside their job performance. Perhaps they don't look like the rest of the team, they have a different religious affiliation, or a different sexual orientation. They might not participate in after-work functions with the team where alcohol is involved. In some extreme situations, an employee might be labeled a low performer due to rejected romantic advances from the manager. (This last one seems crazy, but I've seen it happen once.)
texts.text: For example, a manager might label an employee as a low performer due to factors outside their job performance. Perhaps they don't look like the rest of the team, they have a different religious affiliation, or a different sexual orientation. They might not participate in after-work functions with the team where alcohol is involved. In some extreme situations, an employee might be labeled a low performer due to rejected romantic advances from the manager. (This last one seems crazy, but I've seen it happen once.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The problem shows up when the company tries to do a layoff like this:
texts.text: The problem shows up when the company tries to do a layoff like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
SELECT *
FROM employees
WHERE performance_level = "unacceptable"
ORDER BY RAND()
LIMIT 100
texts.text:

FROM employees
WHERE performance_level = "unacceptable"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Suddenly there are people on the low performing list who don't belong there. However, at the executive level, they have no idea about the dubious performance reviews.
texts.text: Suddenly there are people on the low performing list who don't belong there. However, at the executive level, they have no idea about the dubious performance reviews.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This is a fast path to wrongful termination lawsuits.

texts.orig: Let's get back on something positive. How do we avoid taking these events personally and push through to something better?

texts.orig: Use your newfound power

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As an engineer, you have more control over customer outcomes after a layoff than ever before. Confused? I'll explain.
texts.text: As an engineer, you have more control over customer outcomes after a layoff than ever before. Confused? I'll explain.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've worked in engineering, management, and leadership roles in technology since 2004. In many situations, engineers struggle to change business processes and persuade business-minded people to change their outlook on a topic. There's another blog post on here about  persuasion engineering  that might be worth reading.
texts.text: I've worked in engineering, management, and leadership roles in technology since 2004. In many situations, engineers struggle to change business processes and persuade business-minded people to change their outlook on a topic. There's another blog post on here about  persuasion engineering  that might be worth reading.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Layoffs shake the foundations of any company, including the processes that brought the company to that point. It's a great time to question any of these processes. Does the process save time? Does it benefit customers? Does it need to be modified? Should we throw it away completely?
texts.text: Layoffs shake the foundations of any company, including the processes that brought the company to that point. It's a great time to question any of these processes. Does the process save time? Does it benefit customers? Does it need to be modified? Should we throw it away completely?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm not suggesting that you approach all processes and business justifications with immediate contempt, but have the courage to ask questions about them. Even long-held beliefs should be questioned.
texts.text: I'm not suggesting that you approach all processes and business justifications with immediate contempt, but have the courage to ask questions about them. Even long-held beliefs should be questioned.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The number one fear I have as someone who stays when a layoff happens is this: What if we're too afraid to speak up? What if we're too afraid to take a leap? What if fear of being next on the layoff list prevents us from doing something amazing?
texts.text: The number one fear I have as someone who stays when a layoff happens is this: What if we're too afraid to speak up? What if we're too afraid to take a leap? What if fear of being next on the layoff list prevents us from doing something amazing?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can be an advocate for change. It's the best environment to make a change and think differently about where the company can best serve its customers.
texts.text: You can be an advocate for change. It's the best environment to make a change and think differently about where the company can best serve its customers.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It could end in one of two ways:
texts.text: It could end in one of two ways:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You change the future of the company for the better and delight your customers
texts.text: You change the future of the company for the better and delight your customers

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You're on the termination list for the next layoff
texts.text: You're on the termination list for the next layoff

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On the first one, you've done something truly incredible and you will likely receive recognition for it. You'll also feel more engaged in your work.
texts.text: On the first one, you've done something truly incredible and you will likely receive recognition for it. You'll also feel more engaged in your work.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: On the second one, if the company decides you rocked the boat too much and decides to let you go, it's for the best. You're likely dealing with some levels of middle management who lead with fear rather than a drive to improve. Don't take it personally and look for the next opportunity.

texts.orig: Personally, I'd rather go out in a blaze of glory trying to make the company a better place. 😉
